items.title: Canada's economy shrank by 0.3% in August
items.description: Canada's economy shrank in August against widespread expectations of no growth, Statistics Canada data showed on Friday, but an advanced estimate pointed out the economy might escape a recession in the third quarter.

items.title: Carney says China doesn't share concerns about ‘foreign interference'
items.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney said China does not grasp Canada's level of concern on "foreign interference" after meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping.

items.title: Canada announces first critical minerals projects under G7 partnership
items.description: The 25 initiatives include purchase agreements for a Quebec graphite mine and investments to scale up a rare earth elements refinery in Ontario.

items.title: Carney and Xi agree to tackle 'irritants' in Canada-China relationship
Summerland B.C. winery says imported fruit is hurting the local market
items.description: “There are still quite a bit of grapes left on the vines,” Gill said. “We’re still getting inquiries, we’re turning people away at this point.”

items.title: Penticton accused of too little public consultation on proposed tiny home development
items.description: The City of Penticton wants to build a tiny home community for the unhoused population on a piece of land along Dartmouth Road.

items.title: CFL suspends Alouettes' Oakman ‘indefinitely' for policy breach
items.description: The Canadian Football League has suspended Shawn Oakman of the Montreal Alouettes 'indefinitely' for allegedly breaching its policy on gender-based violence and harassment.

items.title: General strike in Alberta possible after back-to-work legislation
‘No change to property sale procedures' B.C. gov't says of Richmond homes in Cowichan land ruling
items.description: Debate over the ruling was reignited earlier this month after the City of Richmond sent a letter to a group of 150 property owners in the land claim area.

items.title: ‘I did apologize to the President,' Carney says on U.S. anti-tariff ad
items.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney confirmed he apologized to U.S. President Donald Trump after an Ontario anti-tariff ad aired in the U.S.

items.title: ‘I've kind of done it all': Zamboni driver from Halifax retiring after 50 years
items.description: Kelly Saunders is hanging up the keys after a multi-decade career, which saw him play an integral role in some of Halifax's biggest moments on ice.

items.title: Saskatoon police officer faces assault charge after ‘off-duty social gathering'
items.description: A Saskatoon police officer is facing an assault charge after the Saskatchewan police watchdog's investigation into an off-duty social gathering from last fall.

items.title: How one North Vancouver school Is redefining education for neurodiverse learners in B.C.
A Guide to the Modern-Day Scaries of 2025
items.description: Here’s a spooky list of the real-life frights that keep us up at night.

items.title: A photographer captured a Windsor, Ont., woman in the 'roughest time.' The family can't get the pics deleted
items.description: Loved ones of a Windsor woman want photos taken of her on the city’s streets, during an active drug addiction, removed from social media. The woman in the photos is Alicia Newman and she died several years ago.
